column9: We try the AUTHENTICATE PLAIN command and when that fails we fall back to using the LOGIN command. It looks like by the time K-9 Mail tries to read the response to the LOGIN command the connection has already been closed by the server. That causes us to treat this as a connection failure rather than an authentication failure.

column9: I can't reproduce this, but I know it's happened to me too a few times before. While the stacktrace is the same, I think this is a completely different issue than #549. Basically, our fragments stay alive beyond the activity lifecycle so that we can keep logging the user in even if they rotate the screen. This gets a little messy though because we could be trying to finish the activity while it's in no-man's land between an onDestroy and an onCreate. My guess is that since the phone you mentioned is older and slower, it takes much longer for the activity to recreate and attach itself to our fragments thus increasing the likelihood of a crash. Anyway, hopefully #618 will fix this kind of issue once and for all.

Introduces a new authentication mode, 'None', to deal with the particular case of cloning from publicly accessible repositories which do not need to be pushed to. To achieve this, the following changes were made:

New main_menu_no_auth variant for overflow menu that only has a pull option
Plumbing in GitOperation to directly execute the command provided
Code cleanup and logic tweaks in GitServerConfigActivity to handle the new option
UI change from MaterialButtonToggleGroup to RadioGroup for connection mode to adjust for
being unable to fit another button.

column8: When a user navigates away from the Change Email Address screen while /user/change_email request is in progress, HTTP failed error is received and the new email address is not reflected in the app even though it gets changed on the server. It is not updated even after a forced refresh. The only way to see the new email is to log out and log in with the new email.
column9: I moved the disposables.clear() in the onCleared() viewmodel to the doFinally { } in the changeEmail() function. Clear composite disposables in the onCleared() inflict the http request canceled by the client upon ChangeEmailFragment destroyed, since the http request already sent and being processed by server with http canceled by client we lost our response and can't update email in the AccountManager. By moving disposables.clear() to the doFinally{} we ensure that the http call not canceled when we navigate from the ChangeEmailFragment and the disposable cleared upon request finished.

column8:
It turns out that refreshing the access token happened on the thread on which the App itself was created. I.e. in most cases, the UI thread. This would in turn cause an android.os.NetworkOnMainThreadException exception, which was swallowed by OS and it would retry every 10 seconds.

This was especially problematic for apps re-opening with an already logged-in user, as the access token needed to be refreshed to start sync. This would effectively block Realms from being opened, making the app appear deadlocked. The only solution was logging out and back again.
column9: In order to fix this, I turned the NetworkTransport Async, so it now uses an internal handler thread to run all network requests. This means that no matter how a network request is started, it will always run on a worker-tread. This causes a little bit of overhead, but given that a network request is already pretty slow, this seems acceptable.

column8: Sync certificate verify failed only in android

column8: Signing in with Multi-factor doesn't work (both Java and Kotlin). After enrolling in MFA with my phone number, I signed out and tried to sign in with EmailPasswordFragment. Entering my email password and clicking "SIGN IN" brought me back to the start of the app instead of showing me the MFA page. No SMS verification code was sent and I wasn't able to sign in.
column9:
This PR should fix the MFA sign in flow.
There are a couple of things going on here:

On the java quickstart: a NullPointerException was being thrown in MultifactorSigninFragment#onViewStateRestored. This PR fixes it by adding a null check.
On the Kotlin quickstart: the onCreateView method was not inflating the layout for MultifactorSignInFragment.
For both languages: The navigation was a bit confusing and was preventing the mfa sign in flow from completing successfully.
Previous flow: EmailPassword -> Mfa (checks if sign in is required) -> (if yes) MfaSignIn -> back to Mfa (the app was not coming back to Mfa)
New flow: EmailPassword -> MfaSignIn -> Mfa

column8:
It looks like KP2A has a way to differentiate between an app's username and password fields.
Therefore, it should be possible to know what field (from an app that requires an input) the user calls KP2A from.
My idea is that if the user wants, he/she can tell KP2A that the field corresponds to TOTP and have it filled directly next time.
Ideally, the user could specify in KP2A to use TOTP or any other field if he/she wants for that specific call to Autofill but it might be harder to implement I think.

column9:
Approach
According to #1163 (comment):

Set upper range for FB Login SDK to >=13.1.0 <14.0.0 in this PR
Merge this PR with a major version increase, as it may be a breaking change. The FB Login SDK is currently added as api, so it can transitively accessed if the developer adds the Parse SDK also as api to their app. Since the FB SDK has some braking changes with 13.x, we need to consider that also a breaking change for the Parse SDK.

column8: No Precise Error Message After Error Due to Password Change
column9:
I identified the source of all these Errors (Which is No Accurate Information Provided to the User as to why an operation has failed because of a Single Type Of Exception that is getting lost due to Multiple layers of method calls), Hence I made a separate Exception Class for that Exception called - IvalidLoginTokenException so that it is easier to Identify and Propagate it.

Then I handled that Exception for each of the cases and since all of these Exceptions are the same their action is also Similar which is to Notify the user that Their Login Session has Expired Due to Password Change and They Must Login Again

column8: Verification attempts during initial sync on the SS proxy fail completely
column9: The verification prompt won't be displayed after logging in: this is kind of a workaround, but I switched from listening to RustSyncService.state() to RoomListService.state(). For some reason, when RustSyncService emits a Running state, the verification controller is not ready to be used yet and the RustVerificationService can't be configured. In fact, it won't be retried until it changes sync state (error, stopped, then running again). This doesn't happen with RoomListService.State.

column8: "Autofill" credentials doesn't work
column9:
How it worked before:Get API client list, find one named "Android app".
If not found, create a new API client. Response is ignored.
Get API client list, find one named "Android app". If a client with that particular name is not found, use any other.
The problem was that sometimes (not sure what it depends on) the list in the third step doesn't contain the newly created client. And if there is no other client (with a different name) to fall back to, the autofill fails.
To work around it I added a 1-second pause before the third step. I think this should do it.
There was also a 3+ years old TODO to use the creation result in step 2 (it contains credentials for the created client). I implemented this part, so it should be a little more optimized now.

column8: Intermittent Failures with Application Passwords Login
column9:
We identify an issue with login where the fact that SelectedSite's operations are not thread-safe can break the login flow, for more information on the exact flow where this happens, please check this comment.
This PR fixes the issue by making SelectedSite thread safe.

column8: Error message not showing in dark mode
column9:
We received a complaint from the HEs that some users are sharing screenshots where the error message was not visible on the site credentials' dialog, and the thought was that it was because using the dark theme.
But after investigating, I found out that this happens regardless of the theme, what happens is that we are showing an empty message.

column8: Jetpack connection is broken for Application Passwords login
column9:
While I couldn't reproduce 10043 consistently like what happened to me on Friday, I found some edge cases where it happens, and my theory is that they are caused by the instability of the https://wordpress.com/jetpack/connect that we use for Application Passwords flow. This PR attempts a way for the user to recover from the error, instead of offering a retry that doesn't help.
The retry logic we have in this screen, allows retrying just the last step, while when this issue occurs, we need to retry the connection step itself, and not just the validation, and this PR does this exactly.

column8: IllegalArgumentException: Required value was null
column9: Start login flow if wpcom email is not present in the response

column8: Login with given site uses that site for wp.com flow
column9:
I am not sure that this fixes the crash, but it may be. This, for sure, fixes another bug, though. The issue comes from the fact that the site URL stored in the app prefs is not deleted in some cases, and that's why the entered URL used later on is the "current site" URL, which leads to the different broken states.

To reproduce the bug

Open a clean app
Log in -> Enter a non WP.com site
Go back to the main screen
Create a new store -> login
Enter wp.com email
Notice that "it looks like is connected to a different wp.com account" error
My not proven theory is that in some cases, if the site entered on step 2 matches the wpcom account, but somehow not wpcom then JP activation flow started and crash happens, because URL from another site is used that we don't have credentials

column8: Unable to load custom login pages from site credentials login screen
column9:
This PR fixes a login issue that occurs when WordPress is installed in a custom subdirectory, and not in the server's root, users might make this change for security reasons to try to hide the login and admin URLs.
It has two changes:

First it fixes the UI of the error dialog.
It updates FluxC to bring the change

column8: App redirects back to MyStore when user clicks on the launcher icon
column9:
This PR updates the launchMode of MainActivity to ensure a new instance is not started when the activity is already at the top of the stack.

This PR doesn't implement an optimal fix as it'd be quite complex and is imo not worth the time at the moment. It seems to me the app misuses theFLAG_ACTIVITY_NEW_TASK -> at least I don't see any reason why we'd need this flag in our app.

The ideal fix imo would be to remove the usage of FLAG_ACTIVITY_NEW_TASK from all the places and rely on the default Android behavior + ensure MainActivity isn't recreated when it's already at the top of the stack.

Either case, this PR only updates the latter part of the code and ensures the MainActivity is not recreated when it's already at the top. This fixes the original issue where the MainActivity used to redirect the user to MyStore screen when it was originally not launched from the OS Launcher but for example from the Login Flow.

column8: When opening Login prologue with language set to Spanish the text is cutout. This most likely happens in other languages where the test is longer than in English. Fix the prologue to make it responsive/resizable, so it ensured the full text is always displayed.
column9: Fixes issues with login prologue not supporting different locales where description test is longer than in English.

column8: Redirect to account mismatch error during site credentials when needed
column9:
This PR fixes the above issue by making sure we show the account mismatch screen when connecting using site-credentials to a site that has Jetpack connected to a different account.

The message was updated to reflect that it's not an account mismatch per se, but it's the fact that the used credentials are for an account that's not connected to Jetpack.
The screen doesn't allow much now, but it will be improved in upcoming PRs, and it's still better than the misleading "Jetpack Required" screen that we were using before.

column8: Unified Login: Incorrect error message and overlapping buttons after entering email that doesn't match a WordPress.com account
column9: Removing the "Try the link below to log in using your site address." portion of the error string displayed to the user when they try to log into WordPress.com with an email address that does not exist. Note that this fix is temporary and is strictly to remove any confusion.

column8: Unified Login: Login doesn't proceed past username/password screen after being redirected there from email/password login
column9: by bypassing the site address check if the user was routed to the username/password screen through the WordPress.com login flow. This fix allows a successful WPcom login to finish successfully. The reason this was an issue in the first place is because the previous login flow did not have a dedicated WPcom login path - there was always a site address.

column8: Unified Login: Google login success but app login does not progress
column9:
There are two different layouts for LoginEmailFragment:

One that has a button to allow the user to login with site credentials (tag: TAG_ALT_LAYOUT)
One that has a button to allow for signing in with Google (tag: TAG).
The issue was that the tags were swapped when creating the instance of LoginEmailFragment so that when the method onGoogleLoginFinished was called we'd attempt to connect to the wrong fragment to call finishLogin().

column8: IllegalStateException: SelectedSite.get() was accessed before being initialized - siteId 1
column9: Fixes #4114 by ensuring we check if the site exists before fetching the user role (since we need the site id). This fix should be fine because once a site is selected, we fetch the user role in SitePickerActivity anyway so this should not break any existing functionality.

column8: java.lang.NullPointerException: Attempt to invoke virtual method Button.setEnabled(boolean)' on a null object reference
column9: Fixes #3761 by adding logic to check for null here since I believe this could happen when the button is null after OnDestroyView but onLoginFinished() is still getting executed. An edge case but the null check here can help since it doesnâ€™t stop the login flow. Rather it would just not disable the button. A crash is much worse in this case since it disrupts the login flow.

column8: Crash when clicking on the help dialog button during login
column9:
Fixes #3511, the cause of the crash is that we are trying to access binding in setEnabled, but setEnabled is called from the base constructor, so binding is null there.
But when checking the code of super.setEnabled, I don't think we need to make any changes ourselves, as the base implementation updates the status for all child views:

column8: NullPointerException: Attempt to invoke virtual method on a null object reference
column9:
Fixes #3154 by adding a null check when user enters a site address during login. I haven't been able to reproduce the issue but it looks like we set the mSiteAddressInput=null when the fragment is destroyed. So if the onTextChanged is called before the mSiteAddressInput could be initialised again, this crash could potentially happen.

Given that we needn't update the mSiteAddressInput field after the fragment is destroyed, it seemed enough to do just a null check here to ensure that this crash doesn't happen again.

column8: Crash in login discovery view
column9: This PR fixes a crash currently happening in 4.1-rc-1 caused by the dark mode product. The Login Discovery Error view was missed during the first round of changes and since it's difficult to get it to be shown, it wasn't failing during testing. The bug is the duplicated +id/toolbar ID assigned in fragment_login_discovery_error.xml layout. When the login library was updated, the toolbar was placed inside an AppBarLayout so using that ID in the <include/> element was erroneously attempting to assign that id to an AppBarLayout instead of a Toolbar and that was causing the crash.
